qas.question: Judges and police officers had to disclose their Freemason membership in what years in England?
Who ended the English Masonic disclosure policy in 2009?
Justice Secretary Jack Straw ended the Masonic disclosure law on what grounds?
Who ended the English Masonic disclosure policy in 2004?
Why did Justice Secretary Jack Straw begin the Masonic closure law?
What democracies always view Freemasonry with trust?
Who was required to not be transparent to the public?

context: Even in <b5_0>modern democracies<b5_0/>, Freemasonry is sometimes viewed with distrust. In the UK, Masons working in the justice system, such as judges and police officers, were <a0_0>from 1999 to 2009<a0_0/> required to disclose their membership. While a parliamentary inquiry found that there has been no evidence of wrongdoing, it was felt that any potential loyalties <b6_0>Masons<b6_0/> might have, based on their vows to support fellow Masons, should be transparent to the public. The policy of requiring a declaration of masonic membership of applicants for judicial office (judges and magistrates) was ended in 2009 by <a1_0><b3_0>Justice Secretary Jack Straw<b3_0/><a1_0/> (who had initiated the requirement in the 1990s). Straw stated that <a2_0><b4_0>the rule was considered disproportionate<b4_0/><a2_0/>, since no impropriety or malpractice had been shown as a result of judges being Freemasons.
